snippet: The study, made public by a women’s advocacy group this week, suggested that while women were not as physically strong, on average, as men, the Marines could successfully integrate women by setting clear standards.
abstract: Women's advocacy group Women in International Security releases to public details of Marine Corps study finding no reduction in morale in combat units that integrated women, nor any increase in sexual assault levels in such units; Marine Corps had previously released four-page summary of report, following extended testing of mixed-gender combat units, that neglected to note these findings.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: The study, made public by a women’s advocacy group this week, suggested that while women were not as physically strong, on average, as men, the Marines could successfully integrate women by setting clear standards.

headline.print_headline: Study by the Marine Corps Finds No Detriment to Morale in Mixed-Gender Combat Units
headline.main: Marine Corps Study Finds No Detriment to Morale in Mixed-Gender Combat Units
